ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was one of the last courses I ever took at Yale, and I'm so glad I did. Leaving Yale and entering the "real world" is a bit terrifying, but this course helped me discover what matters most to me -- and that knowledge will guide me as I move onto the next stage of life. I also met many wonderful people in this course, people I now call my friends. We had countless about not just the readings, but our personal visions of a life worth living. It was beyond enriching, and each of our three essays (Yale's vision of a life worth living, our peers' visions, and our own visions) helped me reflect on what matters in life. I adored this course. Thank you to everyone who made it possible.
different traditions and their values in a life worth living, and helping further develop my own vision

This course got me to reflect a lot about both what has been meaningful for me in life so far and what I want to be meaningful going forward. It also gave me significant perspective on what other people find meaningful and made me appreciate various other belief systems more, which I found surprising as someone who considers themselves not at all religious. One of the best courses I got to take at Yale, particularly good as a last semester senior course.
While we explored different traditions and what they prescribed in a life worth living, this class is inherently introspective. I learned about what I believed a life worth living is.
Insight on various religions and philosophies.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Everything. This course was wonderful in every way. I have no complaints.
I like the intimate seminar setting, we were able to share all of our thoughts openly and Ahmed helped facilitate conversation very well
Retreat is a strength, do the readings and show up to class to make the most of it
Very personal and comfortable space to reflect and share about life, got me to read and think about things I never planned to

Strengths: Community, Survey of readings/course readings, Professor, Plenary speakers.

Weakness: essay length could be restricting.
Sometimes the course isnt synthesized well. Would have better overarching lectures.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially if they want to explore collaboratively the course questions and what makes a life worth living.
Yes, yes, and yes. I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to interrogate their values and figure out what matters to them in life. One of the best courses I've ever taken.
Yes, it gave me insight into the perspectives of other traditions and of my own classmates that I otherwise would've never known
Yes, if you want to better understand yourself and better orient yourself to be fulfilled in life

Yes, take this course before you graduate! Itll change how you think about life. Its a great class to take to reflect on your time at Yale and to be in a better place to shape your perspective on the future.
